column5: Crosswind isn't an issue when you fly a real aircraft.  Dan

Crosswind is an issue when you fly ANY aircraft.. big or small they all have a limit. The great thing about my personal airplane.. once I reach the limit I can usually land across the runway directly onto the ramp into the wind!
Sorry Wayne, I have lots of respect for any pilot.  With rotary wing aircraft we just have the pilot point the nose into the wind and land.  Dan
Oh.. one of those... I don't "do" things that beat the air into submission vs flying ! LOL

This is  the aviation weather forecast from Hamburg airport at the time of this incident:  EDDH 011220Z 29028G48KT 9000 -SHRA FEW011 BKN014 07/05 Q0984 TEMPO 29035G55KT 4000 SHRA BKN008  In bold/underlined is the winds which decoded means the wind was forecast to be from 290 degrees at 28 knots gusting 48 knots and temporarly 290 degrees at 35 gusting 55 knots.  55 Knots = 63 MPH = 105 KPH  The apparently took out a winglet as well -  Whew, lucky
What's the rwy heading at Hamburg?
I think it's 23 but don't forget, the forecasts are in true and the runway is magnetic so could've been more that 60 degrees off?

Im in full agreement with you there Wayne....I have seen much worse than that....he did a bit of a job on the wingtip though but an awesome job just the same.  Picture of it here: http://www.airliners.net/uf/view.file?id=5...e=phpOltUWB.jpg  I bet this pilot would have had a cakewalk landing at the old Kai Tak airport in Hong Kong.....there are some good videos on YouTube of some Kai Tak landings......amazing!  ßill
EDDH  Runways Direction  Length (ft/m)	Surface  05/23	10,660	3,250	Paved 15/33	12,025	3,660	Paved

If you look here: http://home.comcast.net/~bzee1a/   at some of the stills, you can actually see the shock waves (other than the vapour cone) forming on various surfaces of the aircraft. Some amazing photography there....and can you imagine being on one of the boats??  ßill

Okay boys, here's some more fun if you're bored:  Air Portugal in Lisbon:  http://ca.youtube.com:80/watch?v=Id4jeEfhBiE  Korean Air in Hong Kong's old Kai Tak airport. Look closely how he actually touches down before the runway threshold and takes out a runway light or two:  http://ca.youtube.com/watch?v=cub3n4QrCrs&...feature=related
Or this one, brand new to be delivered in 5 days, brakes let go while doing an engine run:      WHOOPS!
Whoops is right... next time maybe he'll back it up to the thrust barrier instead of nosing it up it!
I watched this one live on TV a couple years ago.  No crosswind.  Front landing gear stuck sideways.  http://ca.youtube.com/watch?v=MjNWzPfGWrU
you mean brakes like these???  <object width="425" height="355"><param name="movie" value="
my bet....   He was probably be-headed..  G
Must've scared the crap out of 131 passengers Youtube Video of Air Lufthansa A32 Nearly Crashes Full Cover CNN Story
Saw that on the news last night.  I'm pretty sure I'd have needed a new pair of panties after that if I was on the flight  Joey
yeah saw it a guy here at work is fly out Friday night, on a good day he has to be heavily medicated to fly but after seeing that, he thinks he needs to be in a medically induced coma

Wow...I had a similar experience landing at Pearson....not as extreme, but enough to make the old heart stop for a second and then resume beating at 160 beats per minute!  Same thing...crosswind...I could see we were not parallel to the runway...  The plane sways back and forth across the runway, feels about 20 feet off the ground....  The left wheels hit the ground (we are on an angle)....waiting what seemed like forever for the right wheels to make contact...in reality it was probably about 15 or 20 seconds.  The cabin became completely quiet...I think we were all even holding our breath.  It's not until we taxi at a slow speed that people start to murmur again.  I look at the guy across the aisle from me and he says "I've flown hundreds of time...THAT was interesting".

Hmmm, now that was a little scary to watch!! I'm heading to Greece come the end of May, and have to fly a Luthansa A330 in Munich. Here's hoping for calm winds and sunny skies!!!  Good Fishing,  Justin
woooow, looked like the wind was carrying it, like one of those paper airplanes
Not even close to a crash! The TV  stations do enough fear mongering... don't add it here!
That's just a normal landing for me, what's the problem? Mine are like that without any wind!
Fear its the root of evil or just crapping your pant.  Ken
Some people waste good money going to an amusement park for action like that !
So that was you who scared the hell out of me at Narita in the summer of 1993!
kind of wonder why they attempted to land in the first place?  It looked like it was being hit heavy by cross winds well before they landed.  Cheers!
I know!  I always figured that the airlines should throw in some of this stuff with the cost of the flight. I would really like to do some of that low altitude stuff like the jet fighters do.
I never get that lucky when I fly.  Just the usually, crappy food, flight delays, stinky passangers and safe landings, I am going to start flying Air Lufthansa.
You mean kinda like this:  (Don't forget to hit the play button)  http://jumpcut.com/view?id=C009AF72755211D..._id=&them=1
perodimi...now that was one COOL video!!
Yeah!  I want to do that over Lake Ontario before landing in Toronto!
That looked like a skilled pilot doing a "touch and go". Do not ever forget the individuals that fly airliners are very skilled and excercise very good judgement in handling those machines.
This was not ordinary either bird in jet engine
Wayne, should he have applied a little more right aileron when doing the left rudder?

I really enjoy watching those and hearing some of the stories that some of the seasoned pilots tell... as long as it has no human tragedy of course.  One of my favourite old ones is the story of the time Jose Feliciano's flight was delayed for a long period of time and Jose had convinced the pilot who had been a long time friend of Feliciano's to take his dog for a walk around the plane. Apparently, the look of sheer fright in the passengers' eyes watching their pilot walking a seeing eye dog around the plane was alone worth the price of the flight.

He was givin'r all she had captain....  No landing lights were harmed in the making of this landing....  Rule #1 in aviation... never try to salvage a bad landing approach... go around and see if you can bend it right the second time!

Hey wayne why didnt he know that with the wind blowing sideways like that,he should have never even tried that landing...i would think he got read the riot act for that not so smart move !!!!!should he have not diverted to another airport ???? be fore he even tried that very risky landing??

He knew Shawn... all the way down final approach he knew and had it under control... just got a little extra umph from the wind under the right wing at the wrong time. It's what keeps it interesting and your skills honed. He had it staying on centerline and generally that's a good indicator it will work out fine. If they all went on straight and with a thump...pilots would get pretty complacent. Depending how hard a thump that is......" Was that a landing... or were we shot down?"  He would have been read a bigger "riot act" for getting there and then choosing an alternate and burning a 10 or 20 grand more worth of fuel + all demm passengers ticked off they missed their connecting flight or where their cars are parked!. He landed it just fine on the second attempt.
Nice crab on that plane....  red over white, your alright.
